author: , Ventura County Star
title: Watch as thousands gather at massive iftar table to break Ramadan fast
text: Video shows thousands gathering for mass iftar in Cairo's Matareya neighborhood The streets of Cairo's Matareya neighborhood were lined with hundreds of tables as thousands gathered to break their fast together on the 15th of Ramadan. The annual community meal has been growing ever since it began in 2012 and has been dubbed the longest iftar table in Egypt. The event has taken place every except for two years during the COVID-19 pandemic, [CBS News](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/egypt-cairo-biggest-iftar-ramadan-muslim-holy-month-in-matareya/?linkId=375865201&fbclid=IwAR30GuXfRu5gY58vG09SshxjEi-f8WqFjV0DMQe5rLliUqkrP1hh___GO9k_aem_AUIl_uI0m2Fa7d3yOvvul3lomGpKLS6JGHZtFmyh3G9V1ohArSC_wjk6LHqnroASeqR-a8yie8LuWMv_Tgdu1rN-) reported. There is no official count of how many people took part in the Matareya iftar, but organizers said as many as 30,000 people attended, [Egypt Today](https://www.egypttoday.com/Article/1/131260/Matariyah-iftar-banquet-manifests-ingenuity-of-Egyptian-people-PM-Madbouli) reported. This year's event featured around 700 tables that stretched for more than half a mile across seven alleyways, [Gulf News](https://gulfnews.com/world/mena/egypt-10000-feast-at-cairos-matariya-mega-iftar-on-10th-anniversary-1.101903343) reported. Footage of the event showed packed streets lit with brightly colored Ramadan decorations lining the alleyways of the neighborhood in the eastern part of Cairo. When is Ramadan 2024?: [What is it? Muslims set to mark a month of spirituality, reflection](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2024/03/08/ramadan-2024-when-what/72866014007/) Began with just a few neighbors At its start, the event was just a handful of neighbors breaking their fast together. Hamada Hassan told CBS News that no one had enough space in their home to host everyone, so they set up tables outside. It only continued to grow from there. Gulf News reported organizers begin preparing for the event around two months in advance every year. Preparations include everything from gathering necessary supplies to feed a whole neighborhood, to cleaning and decorating the streets, CBS News reported. Ahmed Ekram, an organizer said this year 10,000 meals were served, Gulf News reported, citing local media. Some in attendance didn't eat, but went to simply enjoy the camaraderie, CBS News reported. Local donations fund the costs of the event, which over the years has seen politicians, celebrities, and diplomats in attendance. â€œWe do not care about the cost, as all the residents of the neighborhood participate in financing the table in order to bring joy and happiness to the people of the region and other neighboring areas," Ahmed Khalaf, one of the organizers of the 2023 event told [Arab News](https://www.arabnews.com/node/2284791/middle-east) at the time.

author: RTL.de
title: Hamburg: Eltern verwirklichen Traum ihrer bei Ahrtal-Flut verstorbenen Tochter
text:
Tochter stirbt bei Ahrtal-Flut â€“ Eltern verwirklichen ihren Traum
â€Die Patisserie war immer ein Traum von Johannaâ€
Was fÃ¼r eine schÃ¶ne Geste!
Mit einer besonderen Patisserie in Hamburg erinnert ein Paar an seine Tochter Johanna, die 2021 bei der Flutkatastrophe im Ahrtal gestorben ist. Den Plan der leidenschaftlichen BÃ¤ckerin und Konditorin haben Ralph und Inka Orth postum verwirklicht. Seit Anfang 2024 betreiben sie die â€PÃ¢tisserie Johannaâ€œ in der Hafencity.
Eine Extra-Praline ist Johanna gewidmet.
â€Die Patisserie war immer ein Traum von Johanna. Johanna wollte schon sehr, sehr frÃ¼h diesen Beruf lernenâ€œ, sagt Vater Ralph Orth. Und sie plante eine eigene Patisserie zu grÃ¼nden. Im April 2021 hatte die gelernte Konditorin aus Bad Neuenahr die Meisterschule beendet. FÃ¼r ihren zukÃ¼nftigen Laden hatte sie schon einen Business-Plan erstellt und ein Logo entwerfen lassen.
Das Paar hatte Hamburg, als eine seiner LieblingsstÃ¤dte, fÃ¼r die Konditorei-ErÃ¶ffnung gewÃ¤hlt und pendelt jetzt zwischen Rheinland-Pfalz und der Hansestadt. Es gibt TÃ¶rtchen, Macarons, GebÃ¤ck und Quiche auch ein Online-Shop gehÃ¶rt dazu. Eine â€Signature-Pralineâ€œ mit Kirsch-Nougat-FÃ¼llung und einem Schmetterling ist Johanna gewidmet.
Lese-Tipp: Flutkatastrophe im Ahrtal: Noch immer macht der BÃ¼rokratiewahnsinn den Anwohnern zu schaffen
Das richtige Rezeptur dafÃ¼r zu finden sei nicht leicht gewesen, sagt Mutter Inka Orth. â€Aber irgendwann war sie wirklich so, wie Johanna sie bei ihrer PrÃ¼fung gemacht hatte.â€œ
Video-Tipp: Unwetter im Ahrtal: Schlimme Erinnerungen an Flutkatastrophe von 2021
Empfehlungen unserer Partner
â€Uns tut das sehr gutâ€
Aber die Patisserie ist auch Erinnerungsort - an den WÃ¤nden hÃ¤ngen Fotos der Verstorbenen. â€Uns tut das sehr gut und es war uns sehr, sehr wichtig.â€œ Durch die Bilder sowie von einem KÃ¼nstler entworfenen Bronze-Statuen lebe sie weiter. â€FÃ¼r uns bedeutet es, dass wir jeden Tag Ã¼ber Johanna sprechen und sie dadurch auch weiterhin mit der Mittelpunkt der Familie ist.â€œ
Streaming-Tipp: Ahrtal - So geht es den Menschen heute
Viele GÃ¤ste kÃ¤men auch wegen der Geschichte der Tochter - einige von ihnen hÃ¤tten auch Schicksale erlebt. â€Manchmal gibt es Kunden, die einfach reinkommen und sagen: Darf ich Sie mal in den Arm nehmen - das ist voll in Ordnung fÃ¼r uns.â€œ Denn trÃ¶stende Worte gebe es fÃ¼r ihre Trauer oft nicht. (dpa)

author: UK News
title: Martin urges tough sanctions on extremist West Bank settlers if violence goes on
text: Martin urges tough sanctions on extremist West Bank settlers if violence goes on The Tanaiste said the targeting of Palestinians in the West Bank was â€˜shockingâ€™ and has to stop now. Sanctions against extremist Israeli settlers guilty of targeting Palestinians in the West Bank should go further than travel bans if the violence persists, the Tanaiste has said. The US and UK have already announced that they will ban such extremist settlers from entering their countries while EU leaders are set to consider similar proposals. It comes after an upsurge in violence in the Israeli-occupied West Bank. Palestinians living in the area have accused Jewish settlers of using the Israel/Hamas conflict in Gaza as a pretence to seize more land and engage in violence in the West Bank. At his end of year media briefing, Micheal Martin was asked whether sanctions should go further than visa bans and whether Israel should be forced to pay for the damage committed by settlers. â€œWe are part of the West Bank consortium (group of EU states and the UK) which is endeavouring to put pressure on Israel to pay for damage to any EU funded infrastructure and most recently there was a school that was funded by Irish Aid that was very badly damaged by Israeli forces,â€ he said. â€œWe believe whatâ€™s happening in the West Bank is shocking, itâ€™s in violation of UN resolutions and in violation of international humanitarian law and weâ€™ve made it clear consistently at UN and other levels that this has to stop now. â€œYes, I think sanctions should go beyond travel bans if this persists. Israel is saying itâ€™s a small minority but the evidence is that the action of settlers has been backed up by the IDF on the ground with Palestinians being attacked and various communities being displaced. â€œThe issue fundamentally is if we are to have any chance of a contiguous Palestinian state the action of the settlers has to stop, particularly with the far right, very religious fundamentalist settlers who almost believe that the biblical reality is this is all of their land and they can displace anybody in their way, that has to stop and the Israeli government has a responsibility to stop that.â€

author: @nationworldnews
title: Cry Of The British Montreal Journal
text: Have you made your New Yearâ€™s resolutions? I do. Itâ€™s not about losing weight or drinking more green tea. My resolution for 2024 is to continue achieving success in the French language. Providing one-on-one answers to Anglos seeking bilingual Quebec. And to remind columnists who regularly complain montreal gazette Stop playing the victim. calimero Since last few days gazette has already published not one, not two, not three, but four columns complaining about the poor fortunes of the oppressed English poor. And itâ€™s only the first week of January! First lesson: Never short of worrying expressions, always on the verge of literal indifference, Toula Drimonis speaks of the â€œpersistent attacksâ€ of the Legault government that uses the language issue as â€œa weaponâ€ against allophones and Anglos. , which are treated as one. â€œThreatenedâ€ to such an extent that they â€œno longer feel they have a future here.â€ [Read Also: "It was a shock": A teen suffering from heart virus was revived after 42 minutes of heart massage](https://nationworldnews.com/it-was-a-shock-a-teen-suffering-from-heart-virus-was-revived-after-42-minutes-of-heart-massage/) Toula Drimonis hopes that in 2024 the government will understand that â€œMontreal is proudly and officially French, but will never be only French, because this city is full of English, Spanish, Arabic, Greek, Vietnamese, Italian, Creole, Armenian, There is also Punjabi, Portuguese. Â» Read me carefully, Madame Drimonis. Montreal will never be anything but French, officially and unofficially. Like Rome is Italian. Like Athens is Greek. And because Toronto is unambiguously and monolingually English. Second lesson: Bill Brownstein is â€œafraidâ€ that after hearing about the franchise clause, Canadians, Americans and even people from â€œthe whole worldâ€ will not feel welcome in Quebec. â€œCynics have raised the possibility of banning tourists who do not speak intermediate level French.â€ On the linguistic front â€œcloudsâ€ and â€œstormsâ€ could have a negative impact on Montrealâ€™s economy, such as a â€œbrain drainâ€ and the city could even become a â€œbackwaterâ€! In short, the seven plagues of Egypt. Just remembering the frogs falling from the sky. Third Lesson: Alison Haines claims that unlike the dysfunctional Legault government and its â€œpopulist outrageâ€, Quebecers are â€œinclusiveâ€ because they like bilingualism, embrace bilingualism, celebrate bilingualism. So itâ€™s great that residents of the city of Montreal speak to each other in both languages! Fourth lesson: Former minister Clifford Lincoln demands that graduates of English-speaking universities speak out loud and clear on CAQ measures. Excellent! I graduated from McGill in 1987. And I applaud the governmentâ€™s demand that graduates leave McGill able to order smoked meats and poutine at Schwartz. Lincoln regretted that the CAQ â€œconstantly and vindictively targets the English minorityâ€, â€œdespicableâ€ and â€œpetty ordersâ€, â€œobsessive prejudiceâ€, â€œhostility towards a linguistic groupâ€ and â€œoutrageous demandsâ€. â€œEnough is enough,â€ he wrote in French. master at our house During the holidays, former PQ leader Jean-FranÃ§ois Lissy went to Club Med in Charlevoix. â€œAt times we could not get service in French, including at reception and the ski rental shop,â€ he wrote on X. In Charlevoix you canâ€™t be served in French, sadly! And meanwhile, the Anglos of Quebec complain of being mistreated? This is obscene!
